t: Jeremiah 20
Pashhur Persecutes Jeremiah
When*p Pashhur the priest, the son of Immer, who was chief officer in the house of the Lord,*s heard Jeremiah prophesying these things,
Pashhur had Jeremiah the prophet beaten and put him in the stocks that were at the upper Benjamin Gate, which was by the house of the Lord.*s
On the next day, when Pashhur released Jeremiah from the stocks, Jeremiah said to him, “Pashhur is not the name the Lord*s has called you, but rather Magor-missabib.

For thus says the Lord,*s ‘Behold, I am going to make you a terror to yourself and to all your friends; and while your eyes look on, they will fall by the sword of their enemies. So I will give over all Judah to the hand of the king of Babylon, and he will carry them away as exiles to Babylon and will slay them with the sword.

I will also give over all the wealth of this city, all its produce and all its costly things; even all the treasures of the kings of Judah I will give over to the hand of their enemies, and they will plunder them, take them away and bring them to Babylon.

And you, Pashhur, and all who live in your house will go into captivity; and you will enter Babylon, and there you will die and there you will be buried, you and all your friends to whom you have falsely prophesied.’ ”
Jeremiah’s Complaint
O*pn Lord,*s You have deceived me and I was deceived; You*ln have overcome me and prevailed. I*ln have become a laughingstock all day long; Everyone*ln mocks me.
For*ln each time I speak, I cry aloud; I*ln proclaim violence and destruction, Because*ln for me the word of the Lord*s has resulted In*ln reproach and derision all day long.

But*ln if I say, “I will not remember Him Or*ln speak anymore in His name,” Then*ln in my heart it becomes like a burning fire Shut*ln up in my bones; And*ln I am weary of holding it*i in, And*ln I cannot endure it.*i

For*ln I have heard the whispering of many, “Terror*ln on every side! Denounce*ln him;*i yes, let us denounce him!” All*ln my trusted friends, Watching*ln for my fall, say: “Perhaps*ln he will be deceived, so that we may prevail against him And*ln take our revenge on him.”

But*ln the Lord*s is with me like a dread champion; Therefore*ln my persecutors will stumble and not prevail. They*ln will be utterly ashamed, because they have failed, With*ln an everlasting disgrace that will not be forgotten.
Yet,*ln O Lord*s of hosts, You who test the righteous, Who*ln see the mind and the heart; Let*ln me see Your vengeance on them; For*ln to You I have set forth my cause.
Sing*ln to the Lord,*s praise the Lord!*s For*ln He has delivered the soul of the needy one From*ln the hand of evildoers.
Cursed*ln be the day when I was born; Let*ln the day not be blessed when my mother bore me!
Cursed*ln be the man who brought the news To*ln my father, saying, “A*ln baby boy has been born to you!” And*iln made him very happy.
But*ln let that man be like the cities Which*ln the Lord*s overthrew without relenting, And*ln let him hear an outcry in the morning And*ln a shout of alarm at noon;
Because*ln he did not kill me before birth, So*ln that my mother would have been my grave, And*ln her womb ever pregnant.
Why*ln did I ever come forth from the womb To*ln look on trouble and sorrow, So*ln that my days have been spent in shame?
